key_title: Key to the species of Lepidosperma

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Monocotyledons
Key to the genera of Cyperaceae

source.author: Wilson, K.L.
source.title: Cyperaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: Modified from: Wilson, K.L. (1994). Cyperaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Culms flat, or with 1 face convex, or concavo-convex, or biconvex with 2 clearly defined acute margins

Culms terete, or compressed so as to be oval in cross-section or irregularly angular, sometimes grooved, or more or less biconvex with 1 flat acute margin and the other rounded to broad-acute (L. semiteres)
Rachis straight or scarcely curved
Rachis flexuose (usually strongly so)
Inflorescence blackish or very dark red-brown; fertile glumes 5–7 mm long; culms 20–60 cm high, 0.5–1 mm diam
Inflorescence pale red-brown to pale grey-brown; fertile glumes 7–11 mm long; culms 30–200 cm high, 0.7–2 mm diam

Hypogynous scales 3, plus 3 similarly swollen stamen filaments; leaf-sheaths very dark red-brown to dark grey-brown, straw-coloured above; fertile glumes scarcely longer than basal sterile glumes; nut 4–5 mm long
Hypogynous scales 5 or 6; stamen filaments not swollen; leaf-sheaths straw-coloured to reddish; fertile glumes to twice as long as sterile glumes; nut 2.8–4 mm long
Spikelets in dense clusters
Spikelets loosely arranged along spike-like branches of inflorescence
Culms subterete with 1 acute, flat margin, or irregularly angular, or biconvex with 1 acute margin and 1 rounded
Culms terete or slightly compressed but without acute margins
Leaf-sheaths blackish or very dark red-brown; spikelets appressed to rachis
Leaf-sheaths straw-coloured, reddish, or dark yellow-brown; spikelets more or less spreading from rach
Leaf-sheaths dark yellow-brown to dark grey-brown, occasionally dark reddish near apex; spikelets 5–7 mm long; fertile glumes 5–6 mm long
Leaf-sheaths straw-coloured to reddish; spikelets 6–10 mm long; fertile glumes 7–9 mm long
Culms rather spongy, compressible, strongly biconvex
Culms tough, not or scarcely compressible, flat to biconvex
Inflorescence with loosely arranged spikelets and/or small inflorescence with few spikelets
Inflorescence with densely clustered, numerous spikelets
Inflorescence with long, at least somewhat spreading, branches, 7–65 cm long
Inflorescence spike-like or with short branches more or less appressed to main axis, 0.8–8 cm long
Culms with margins scabrous, usually viscid, often ciliate
Culms with margins smooth or scabrous but not viscid or ciliate
Culms biconvex, or margins flat with central biconvex ridge, or strongly convex on 1 face and flat on the other, 70–180 cm high, 5–15 mm wide
Culms flat, or slightly convex on 1 face, or concavo-convex, 30–100 cm high, 2–8 mm wide
Rachis flexuose
Rachis straight or scarcely curved
Leaves exceeding inflorescences (to twice as long)
Leaves shorter than inflorescences
Spikelets mostly 3.5–4 mm long; culms usually biconvex
Spikelets mostly 5–8.5 mm long; culms usually flat or concavo-convex
Culms strongly biconvex in cross-section, with finely scabrous, extremely sharp and cutting margins; convined to swampy heathlands of the far east (near Genoa)
Culms flat, plano-convex, weakly biconvex or with a pronounced central biconvex ridge; margins smooth or scabrous but not extrememly sharp
Margins scabrous
Margins smooth
Culms with central biconvex ridge, 5–20 m wide; mostly confined to coastal dunes and headlands
Culms flat, plano-convex or concavo-convex, 3–7(–10) mm wide; mostly lowland heaths and woodlands

Nut (including hypogynous scales) >3 mm long, minutely hispid at apex; inflorescence dense or somewhat diffuse, but spikelets not usually aggregated in distinct clusters; bracts (other than main inflorescence bract) usually not obvious

Nut (including hypogynous scales) <3 mm long, glabrous throughout; inflorescence typically of distinct clusters, each usually with a prominent subtending bract (but these sometimes breaking off before maturity)
